etymology.description: 糖(sugar) + 葫芦(gourd) = “sugary gourd,” a sugar-coated fruit skewer resembling a small gourd.
etymology.interpretation: Highlights the sugar coating and the gourd-like look of fruits strung on a stick; in practice it refers to hawthorn berries coated in hard syrup.
etymology.simplification: 蘆 → 芦 by adopting the simplified grass radical 艹 and simplifying the phonetic 盧 to 卢; other characters unchanged.

parts.english: gourd; calabash; cucurbit; used in plant names
reed; bulrush; (in 葫芦) gourd; reed plant

examples.chinese: 冬天街头常能看到糖葫芦(冬天街頭常能看到糖葫蘆)。
examples.pinyin: Dōngtiān jiētóu cháng néng kàndào tánghúlu.
examples.english: In winter you can often see candied hawthorn on the streets.

examples.chinese: 红艳的糖衣包着山楂，酸甜可口(紅豔的糖衣包著山楂，酸甜可口)。
examples.pinyin: Hóngyàn de tángyī bāo zhe shānzhā, suāntián kěkǒu.
examples.english: A bright red sugar shell coats the hawthorn, tasting sweet and tart.

examples.chinese: 小贩把糖葫芦串在竹签上(小販把糖葫蘆串在竹籤上)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎofàn bǎ tánghúlu chuàn zài zhúqiān shàng.
examples.english: Vendors thread the candied hawthorn onto bamboo skewers.
